Sensitivity to protein shakes:

I had an episode of sensitivity to protein shakes some years back. Was doing weights. Decided to supplement with one protein shake after workout. No calorie increase in diet. No extra protein or carbs elsewhere. Just one shake after workout. I remember the brand - Myoplex.

Weight skyrocketed. Fat buildup was rapid. I immediately stopped. Weight gain stopped but never came down. I increased cardio, improved fitness level, but much of the old weight remains.

entries.title: 6 Reasons Your Weight Fluctuates So Much
entries.snippet: Weight fluctuations of 2–5 pounds over a week or even a single day are normal and often result from changes in fluid retention. This article identifies six key reasons behind these shifts: (1) Diet—particularly intake of sodium or carbohydrates—can significantly affect water retention and weight. While high-carb or salty foods increase water retention, low-carb diets temporarily reduce weight by depleting water stored with glycogen. (2) Hydration—water is heavy, so consuming fluids or being dehydrated can alter scale readings. (3) Exercise can help reduce fluid buildup by increasing lymphatic flow. (4) Hormonal changes due to menstruation, menopause, or thyroid function can affect both water retention and appetite. (5) Certain health conditions alter metabolism or fluid balance. (6) Medications, especially those that impact appetite or water retention, can lead to temporary weight gain. While minor weight changes are typical, repeated significant shifts, known as weight cycling, could harm metabolic and heart health. Those struggling with weight concerns or disordered eating are encouraged to seek professional support, including from the National Eating Disorders Association (NEDA).

entries.title: Glycogen
11 Simple Tricks to Lose Water Weight and De-Bloat
entries.snippet: To effectively reduce water weight and alleviate bloating, adopting several lifestyle and dietary changes can help. Key strategies include lowering salt and carbohydrate intake, which prevent the body from retaining excess water. Staying well-hydrated paradoxically supports fluid balance by signaling the body not to hold onto water. Regular physical activity promotes sweating and helps distribute water to muscles. Consuming foods rich in electrolytes like potassium and magnesium aids in balancing fluid retention. Quality sleep is crucial as it helps regulate hormones that impact fluid balance. Eating nutrient-dense, fiber-rich foods reduces inflammation and supports normal water retention levels. Caution is advised when using natural diuretics, as overuse can lead to dehydration. Managing stress is also vital, since high cortisol levels can contribute to water retention. Avoiding artificial sweeteners, particularly sugar alcohols, helps prevent bloating. For those experiencing swelling, compression garments and leg elevation can enhance circulation and reduce fluid buildup. Generally, water weight is a temporary issue, but persistent or new swelling should prompt medical evaluation, especially if accompanied by other symptoms such as warmth, redness, or pain. These natural methods can help individuals feel lighter and more comfortable without drastic measures.

entries.title: Nestle launches protein shots for US weight-loss drug users
entries.snippet: Nestle has introduced protein shots in the US targeting individuals using weight-loss drugs. Called Boost Pre-Meal Hunger Support, these shots aim to naturally suppress appetite by boosting the GLP-1 hormone, thereby promoting satiety. This initiative by Nestle reflects its strategy to penetrate the growing weight-loss product market. Priced at $10.99 for a pack of four, these shots contain 10 grams of whey protein, 45 calories, 1 gram of sugar, and are fat-free. While these shots complement GLP-1 drugs, their long-term efficacy is yet to be fully determined. Nestle also launched protein-enriched pizzas and pastas earlier this year, adapting to the increasing demand in the obesity drug market, projected to reach $150 billion annually within a decade. Their formula, based on peptides, is designed for quick digestion and prolonged interaction with intestinal receptors to release GLP-1. Research shows it effectively reduces glucose levels post-meal, demonstrating potential for aiding weight loss.

parts:
Short version: this wasn’t a “sensitivity to protein.” The most likely story is (i) you accidentally added a daily 200–300 kcal meal-replacement shake (Myoplex) on top of your diet, (ii) the shake’s carbs + high sodium rapidly pulled in water and glycogen so the scale “skyrocketed,” and (iii) once that weight (fat + water + some lean mass) was on, your body defended the higher weight (“set-point”/“settling-point” physiology), so later cardio had less effect than expected.

Here’s the evidence-based breakdown and what to do next.

## What probably happened (mechanisms, in order of likelihood)

1) **Hidden calorie surplus from the shake itself.**  
   Myoplex “Original/Maximum Muscle Builder” is a *meal replacement*, not a pure protein isolate. Typical labels: ~**300 kcal** with ~**42 g protein, ~20 g carbs, ~7–9 g fat** per 16–17 oz RTD serving; sodium around **~610 mg** per bottle. citeturn0search0turn0search5turn0search10  
   A single 300 kcal addition each day → over 60 days:  
   - 300 × 60 = **18,000 kcal**.  
   - Using the standard conversion **≈7,700 kcal/kg fat**, that surplus alone can add **≈2.3 kg of fat** (18,000/7,700 ≈ 2.34). The 7,700 kcal/kg figure is the classical Wishnofsky value used in modeling; it’s an approximation but suitable for order-of-magnitude estimates. citeturn3search1

2) **Rapid early “skyrocket” = water + glycogen + sodium.**  
   Carbohydrate repletion after training stores glycogen with **~3 g water per gram glycogen**, so a few hundred grams swing in glycogen can move **~1–2 kg** of scale weight fast. Sodium (~610 mg per bottle) adds further transient water retention. citeturn0search4turn0search9turn0search0

3) **Energy compensation blunted the effect of your added cardio.**  
   Humans often *compensate* for exercise (eat a bit more; move a bit less the rest of the day; other metabolic savings), so total daily energy out doesn’t rise 1-for-1 with training volume. That helps health but limits fat loss if diet isn’t adjusted. Evidence supports “constrained TEE”/energy-compensation models and variable NEAT responses. citeturn2search1turn2search2turn2search4turn2search17

4) **Defended higher weight (set-point/settling-point).**  
   After weight gain, homeostatic mechanisms (appetite, metabolic adaptation) can defend the new level, making loss harder than you’d expect from cardio alone. citeturn0search2turn0search7

5) **Less likely contributors.**  
   - **Dairy/lactose or sweetener GI effects** can cause bloating, but that’s *water/volume*, not persistent fat mass.  
   - **Creatine** wasn’t standard in Myoplex *Original* (some EAS products do include creatine; check specific SKUs), but if present it would mainly add intracellular water, not fat. citeturn1search10  
   - **Whey’s insulin/incretin response** actually tends to *improve* post-prandial glycemia and satiety in trials; it doesn’t drive fat gain absent a calorie surplus. citeturn0search3turn0search8

## A blunt take on causality
You wrote “No calorie increase in diet… Just one shake after workout.” That *is* a calorie increase unless you replaced something else gram-for-gram. Given Myoplex’s profile (≈300 kcal + high sodium), it is entirely sufficient to explain rapid scale gain (water/glycogen first, then fat if continued) and the stickiness thereafter via defended-weight physiology. citeturn0search0turn0search5

## How to unwind it (practical, data-driven plan)

**A) Recalibrate the baseline (2 weeks).**  
- Weigh *daily on waking*, track a **7-day moving average** to suppress water noise.  
- Log food with a scale. Don’t change intake yet—just measure.  
- If your 7-day average is flat, that’s your maintenance intake.

**B) Create a small, durable deficit.**  
- Target **–300 to –500 kcal/day** from that measured maintenance. At that deficit, expect ~0.3–0.7% of body weight loss per week once water noise settles, acknowledging compensation. citeturn2search2  
- **Protein:** 1.6–2.2 g/kg/day; spread ≥25–35 g per meal (leucine threshold).  
- **Carbs:** cluster around training; keep day-to-day variation modest to avoid big glycogen water swings.  
- **Sodium:** aim **1.6–2.3 g/day** total; large day-to-day swings will mask fat loss on the scale. (Your Myoplex serving alone was ~0.6 g.) citeturn0search0  
- **NEAT:** prioritize steps and daily movement (8–12k/d) over piling on more formal cardio—this counters compensation better. citeturn2search12

**C) Strength remains, cardio smart.**  
- Keep **2–4 resistance sessions/week** to preserve lean mass; sprinkle cardio for fitness, not as the primary fat-loss lever.

**D) If you want shakes at all, change the product.**  
- Choose a **whey isolate or casein** with **~120–150 kcal, 24–30 g protein, ≤2 g carbs, ≤2 g fat, ≤150 mg sodium** per scoop, mixed with water. That gives the satiety/anabolic upside without stealth calories and sodium bloat typical of meal-replacements like Myoplex. (Whey’s metabolic effects are generally favorable in RCTs.) citeturn0search3turn0search8

**E) Monitor and adjust.**  
- After 3–4 weeks, if your **7-day average** isn’t trending down, trim another **100–150 kcal/day** or add **~2k steps/day**—small, measured changes to outpace compensation. citeturn2search1

**F) Sanity checks (optional but useful).**  
- One **DEXA** or a good **waist/hip tape series** every 4–8 weeks to verify fat vs lean changes (scale can mislead).  
- If your original gain was unusually large/fast *and* you truly didn’t add calories, consider ruling out medical contributors with your clinician (TSH/FT4, fasting glucose or HbA1c, meds review, etc.).  

## Bottom line
Myoplex didn’t “sensitize” your body to store fat; it quietly added calories, carbs, and sodium. The fast jump was mostly water + glycogen on top of a new surplus; the stubbornness since is classic energy-compensation and defended-weight physiology. Switch to a low-calorie, low-sodium protein *isolate* (or whole-food protein), run a small, steady deficit, and track with 7-day averages—you should see the true trend once water noise is tamed. citeturn0search0turn0search4turn2search1turn0search2

If you want, I can sketch a 12-week cut template (macros + weekly adjustments) tailored to a target body weight; just give me your current weight/height/age and training frequency.
